Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Connecticut College project: S-STEM Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics is a continuation of an existing and effective four year "Science Leaders" program which targets traditionally underrepresented students in science. The project builds on that success and expects to increase even more underrepresented students majoring in science by adding two new features: a summer bridge program prior to the freshman year and a study group program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Science Leaders program has at its core the goal of increasing the number of women and underrepresented students graduating from Connecticut College with a degree and research experience in the sciences. Students admitted to the program are from socio-economically disadvantaged backgrounds and priority is given to students of color, first-generation college students, students with disabilities, and women in mathematics, computer science and physics. The Science Leaders Program prepares these students for a wide range of science-related careers and provides a solid foundation for graduate study or medical school.

Data shows that the program is successfully meeting its goal. Seventy-one percent of Science Leaders students are female and eighty percent are domestic students of color. Three students are physically disabled and three pairs of siblings have matriculated into the Science Leaders program. The overall four-year graduation rate for Science Leaders is 93%, which is higher than that for all Connecticut College students in the same time frame. The six-year graduation rate for Science Leaders is 97%. It should be noted that the Science Leaders program admits all students from underrepresented groups that have expressed an interest in the sciences, not just the best students. With the end of this NSF grant we will continue the Science Leaders program at its current size (approximately 15 new admitted students each year).

Science Leaders receive scholarship aid, rigorous mentoring and support, career preparation and counseling, and assistance with applying to graduate or medical school. The program currently includes the following components:

  • Recruiting at high schools in the Northeast, particularly DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, NY;
  • Orientation – 5 days, with a focus on cohort building and getting acquainted with the campus and faculty.
  • Advising – All Science Leaders have the same academic adviser.
  • First Year Seminar – All participants take the same First Year Seminar, designed specifically for the Science Leaders program and taught by their academic adviser. The seminar includes a 4-5 day field trip.
  • Peer Tutoring – facilitated peer tutoring by Science Leaders in gateway courses.
  • Summer Research – funding and guidance to start summer science research early.
